abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcomes, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. A key lesson is, that in
            a difficult post-conflict situation characterized by limited
            government capacity, the project's choice of
            institutional arrangements featuring performance based
            contracting of service providers for implementation and
            management has lend itself to a rapid scaling up of both
            community-driven development (CDD), and labor intensive
            public works activities. A related lesson is that the
            establishment of such arrangements takes time, and
            expectations regarding how quickly operations can begin on
            the ground, need to be realistic. Furthermore, in a
            post-conflict context where rapid delivery of a "peace
            dividend" is critical to establish or maintain the
            credibility of government vis-à-vis the population,
            implementing agencies need to manage the challenge of
            maintaining engineering quality of sub-projects (as has been
            the issue in the community empowerment component), or of
            providing meaningful sub-projects (as has been the issue in
            the public works component, where villagers have questioned
            the usefulness of types of road repair that would only bring
            short-term benefits). Consultations with agencies that have
            prior experience of working in the local context is crucial
            for developing a sound implementation approach, and
            contributes at the same time to establish buy-in and
            commitment to key project principles. Other lessons address
            public works, institutional sustainability, and the
            introduction of innovative development approaches, and
            notably, Bank efficiency in delivery of assistance to weak
            client governments in post-conflict situations is critically
            dependent on having both operational and procurement,
            disbursement, and financial management staff on long-term
            assignments in the country office from the start of the
            operational presence.
